title: Is Tik Tok really as bad as Donald Trump says it is? - Quora
tags: Presidents of the United States of America

response.answer_text: “Is Tik Tok really as bad as Donald Trump says it is?” It’s almost axiomatic that if Trump says something is bad, then it’s good, or at least not as bad as he says it is. The fuss about Tik Tok seems to centre on the idea that it allows the Chinese Government to spy on teens discussing their social lives, videos of animals being cute, and possibly videos exposing police brutality in various countries. I don’t see why they shouldn’t, but I also don’t see why they would want to. More importantly: Do people really think that their communications on Twitter, Facebook, Quora etc. are secret? If the Chinese Government did want to know that some teenage girl thinks the boy in her video is cute and her friends agree, they could find out without any difficulty at all, whatever platform the girls used to express their feelings. Anything more important to the national interest than that won’t be posted on Tik Tok. And why is it worse for the Chinese Government to know that American girls like American boys than for the American Government to know it, and also for the American Government to know that Chinese girls like Chinese boys? If spying on such matters is happening at all, you can be sure their own Government is involved. Trump’s accusations are just part of his campaign to distract his supporters’ attention from his own crimes and focus their hatred on the enemy du jour, in this case China. For Hitler it was Jews, for Trump it’s China and brown/black people, but it really doesn’t matter who the object of hatred is; the intention is to unite his followers (and maybe collect a few more) by capitalising on people’s need to externalise their own fears in the form of hating and blaming some identifiable group for imaginary harm causing all their own problems. It’s always worked and it’s working now: Even some rational people are beginning to see China as an enemy of America.
